Replace.Text: If the Nile was the heart of Egypt, it was the lighthouse at Alexandria that opened it to the world. After Alexander’s reign and the fragmentation of his empire, the rule of Egypt fell to Ptolemy, who sought to make Egypt a viable independent state, oriented outward, towards the Mediterranean. And so, in the 200s BCE, working from an initial proposal by the former conqueror, he ordered the construction of the lighthouse.

The approach to the Nile Delta can be a treacherous thing. Low-lying lands and sunken shoals pose a threat to sailors, and a long and often hidden sandbank threatens approaching ships. This was something those living on the island of Pharos knew well, as they had made a living from scavenging the wrecks of ships that had failed in their approach. But the new city of Alexandria needed a proper approach, a proper gateway for Egypt.

The architect Sostratus designed the lighthouse: over three hundred feet of light stone, built upon a square base, with a mirror at its top, and a fire burning at night. Over all of this was a statue of Zeus, a symbol of rule, and of the Greek domination of Egypt. The wonder was ruined by successive earthquakes in the medieval period, and finally demolished to build a fortress on the site.

Some time in the late 12th century CE the Saudeleur Dynasty arose in the Pohnpei islands of what is now Micronesia. At its capital was a city of canals and artificial islands, built with large slabs of basalt and coral, and interwoven with tombs and residences. Many of these islands were specialized towards particular activities – the construction of canoes, for instance, or the housing of the families of distant chiefs (the better to control their homelands).

The structures housed less than a thousand residents, of which chiefs and priests were a significant, but not majority, part. Indeed, differences in burial and residence (as well as local history) indicate that Saudeleur society was highly stratified, with a ruling chiefly class and elaborate mortuary practices surrounding them. The islands had to import food and water, labor made easier by its elaborate canal system.

Nan Madol is striking in its megalithic architecture, and its legends of a dragon assisting in its construction. For this reason, it has often been the target of pseudoscientific speculation, from the lost continent of Mu to ancient aliens to Graham Hancock’s recent claims. The alternative to these theories is, of course, the idea that a lot of people worked very hard for a long time.

The Yucatan Peninsula is full of sinkholes, areas where soluble limestone is worn down by erosion and creates deep vertical caves – centoes. When the sea rises to fill these caverns, they become “blue holes” – stunning circular blue features of extreme depth. The Great Blue Hole in Belize is one of these – at 410 feet deep, it is not the deepest, but it is the widest at nearly 1000 feet.

Because of the poor circulation of water in such holes, they remain relatively devoid of oxygen and therefore of life, and for this reason remarkably clear. Their blue color comes from the lightness of the sand, the diffraction of light, and the clarity of the water. They can be deadly to divers, especially the Blue Hole in Egypt, because of their deceptive clarity and depth.

Great gouts of water rush skyward with each wave, and with each spout comes a tremendous sound – the “whistle of the nobles,” the Mapu ‘a Vaea. The blowholes are the result of waves being forced through eroded portions of coastal rock on the coast of Tonga, and are associated with the Vaea noble family of that island.
